Najprej so smrdeli, potem šli vsem v slast
V Dragonji so se pomerili v kuhanju vampov na tržaški način. Včasih so jih stregli celo na porokah.
07 Nov 2019, 18:13 by Janez Mužič



Za urejenost kuharjev, kurišča, čistočo in red v kuhinji je bila najbolje ocenjena ekipa Kažeta iz Dragonje.



Na poti od enega kotlička do drugega so se obiskovalci najedli te včasih mnogo bolj razširjene domače jedi.



»Tripe na tržaški način so primorska jed, in na tem koncu smo edini s takim tekmovanjem,« pravi Mirjam Kastelič.



Strukturo vampov, njihov vonj, barvo in seveda okus so ocenjevali Branko Maksimovič, Igor Kramesteter in Mladen Orejaš.



Najboljše je skuhala ekipa ljubiteljev dobre hrane, družbe in veselja Friends for ever iz sv. Petra. FOTOGRAFIJE: Janez Mužič



Miran Velkavrh: »V Ljubljani smo jih kuhali celo v hotelu Union in Turist, da o Figovcu in Šestici ne govorim.«



Bili so priljubljena jed po delavskih menzah in t. i. šoferskih gostilnah, danes pa se jih že kar težko kje naroči.


Med jedi, ki jih nekateri nadvse obožujejo, drugi pa se ob njih kremžijo, vsekakor spadajo goveji vampi. Pripravljajo jih po vsej Sloveniji, a so tripe na tržaški način, kot jim pravijo Primorci, njihova stara jed. Pravzaprav vampe poznajo vse evropske kuhinje, še zlasti španske, francoske in italijanske regije ob Mediteranu.Sosedje Italijani celo zatrjujejo, da so največji svetovni ljubitelji vampov, saj naj bi jih pripravljali na sto načinov in jih imajo za del svoje nacionalne kulinarike. Še zlasti v Rimu so od nekdaj veliki ljubitelji drobovine, ki jo mesarji kot skromnejše in tudi revnejšim dostopnejše meso imenujejo quinto quarto oziroma peta četrtina.


Bili so priljubljena jed po delavskih menzah in t. i. šoferskih gostilnah, danes pa se jih že kar težko kje naroči.

V večnem mestu in še kje je sobota tradicionalni dan za vampe, ki mu pravijo sabato trippa, ko si jih nekateri privoščijo kar za zajtrk. Seveda pri tem poleg okusa, tradicije in morda celo modnosti igra ne tako zanemarljivo vlogo dejstvo, da so v primerjavi z drugim mesom izredno poceni. 
Specialiteta gurmanov
Tudi v Istri in nasploh na Primorskem je to od nekdaj izjemno cenjena jed, a danes je priljubljena predvsem pri starejši generaciji. Znano je, da so si naši predniki, ko so iz vaškega okolja hodili po opravkih v večja mesta, radi za malico v kakšni mestni oštariji privoščili vampe.Kot izvrstno jed so jih radi postregli celo kot enega od slavnostnih obrokov na porokah. Kasneje, po vojni, so postali priljubljena jed po delavskih in drugih menzah, sploh pa v t. i. šoferskih gostilnah, kjer so jih podobno kot golaž oziroma druge poceni malice ponujali tako rekoč vsak dan. A ti časi so mimo. Zamenjale so jih pice in tudi doma se redkeje kuhajo, saj ne nazadnje surovih po supermarketih ni vedno dobiti.


Najboljše je skuhala ekipa ljubiteljev dobre hrane, družbe in veselja Friends for ever iz sv. Petra. FOTOGRAFIJE: Janez Mužič

Poleg tega nekatere ob pripravi moti vonj in bog si ga vedi zakaj tudi mladim, tako kot še kaka druga jed iz drobovine, ne gredo preveč v slast. Morda prav zato, čeprav jih na jedilnikih v kaki bolj fini restavraciji ne boste našli, postajajo specialiteta gurmanov. V zadnjih letih smo dobili celo nekaj tekmovanj v njihovi pripravi oziroma vampijad, na katerih se bolj ali manj ljubiteljski kuharji merijo v njihovi pripravi.Pri nas pravzaprav drugega načina kuhanja vampov kot po tržaško ne poznamo. Seveda gre pri tem za manjše modifikacije in da se sliši bolj domače, jim nekateri pravijo tripe po istrsko. Pripravi se jih s popraženo panceto, čebulo, česnom, peteršiljem in paradižnikovo omako, za zgostitev služijo krušne drobtine. Postreže se jih obvezno s parmezanom in kruhom, še boljši so s polento. In take tržaške tripe so zadnjo soboto v oktobru kuhali na prazniku kostanja v Dragonji, ki so ga že četrto leto popestrili s tekmovanjem v njihovem kuhanju.


Strukturo vampov, njihov vonj, barvo in seveda okus so ocenjevali Branko Maksimovič, Igor Kramesteter in Mladen Orejaš.

»Naša prireditev je vaški praznik, začeli smo jo pred sedmimi leti s kostanjem. Dogajanje ima seveda značaj kulinaričnega druženja in prijateljevanja ter je bilo sprva tematsko obarvano s kostanjem. Ta se namreč te dni lepo prileže ob moštu. Druženju vsako leto dodamo kaj novega, in pred štirimi leti smo dodali kuhanje trip ter otroško delavnico, na kateri za noč čarovnic obdelujejo buče, izdelujejo maske in druge stvari. Vampe kuhajo po vsej Sloveniji, a so na tržaški način primorska jed in na tem koncu smo edini s takim tekmovanjem,« pravi Mirjam Kastelič iz Dragonje, predsednica tamkajšnjega sila aktivnega Razvojnega društva Stena. 
Previdnost pri dodajanju začimb
Osem kuharskih ekip je prišlo iz Dragonje, okoliških vasi Sv. Peter, Puče, Sečovelj in celo iz Poljanske doline ter Buj. Potem ko so jim razdelili po tri kilograme že kuhanih vampov, jim je posebna komisija vseskozi strogo gledala pod prste. Tekmovalci so morali preostale sestavine prinesti sami in poskrbeti za urejeno kuhinjo s svojim kotličkom nad ognjiščem. Ocenjevalo se je kurišče, urejenost kuharjev, prostora, kako čistijo za seboj, proces kuhanja ter še kaj. Na koncu je prišlo seveda na vrsto ocenjevanje jedi, njihove strukture, vonja, barve in okusa.


Na poti od enega kotlička do drugega so se obiskovalci najedli te včasih mnogo bolj razširjene domače jedi.

»Moram priznati, da ni nekega izstopanja, da bi bili kateri izjemno dobri, drugi pa izjemno slabi. Nekateri so pretiravali s kako maščobo, drugi so dodali preveč paradižnikove mezge, eni so bili preslani, sicer pa mi je všeč, da niso pretiravali z začimbami. Večina jih je bila pregostih, preveč rdečih ali pa preveč bledih, so pa za vsako ekipo gotovo njihovi vampi najboljši, in tako je prav. Zato so na neki način vsi zmagovalci,« je povedal predsednik ocenjevalne komisije Mladen Orejaš, sicer kuhar v gostilni Trije lovci iz Šmarij. Poleg njega sta bila v njej še vinogradnik in sadjar iz Dragonje Igor Kramesteter ter upokojeni novinar, sedaj pa piranski 'poklicni' gurman Branko Maksimovič. 
Včasih so bili boljši
V urejenosti kuhinje in ekip je zmagala ekipa Kažeta iz Dragonje, druga je bila ekipa Šavri iz Puč, tretja pa ekipa Puč. Pri ocenjevanju jedi je zmagala ekipa Friends for ever iz sv. Petra pred ekipo Šavri iz Puč in ekipo Kumovi iz Buj. Sicer pa so bili gotovo najbolj zadovoljni obiskovalci prireditve, ki so se med sprehodom od enega kotlička do drugega najedli te včasih mnogo bolj razširjene domače jedi.
4.so tekmovali v kuhanju trip.
Poskušat jih je prišel tudi upokojeni piranski kuhar Miran Velkavrh, ki je med drugim vrsto let kuhal na ladjah Splošne plovbe in po cenjenih piranskih restavracijah. »Za pripravo vampov je pomembna natančnost pri sekljanju čebule, česna, pancete in ostalega, vrstni red dodajanja surovin, predvsem pa previdnost pri dodajanju začimb. So pa bili včasih že sami vampi drugačni in boljšega okusa, kot so danes. To je verjetno pogojevala drugačna reja govedi, njihova paša in tudi način čiščenja ter prvega kuhanja. Danes kupiš kuhane in narezane oziroma pripravljene, mi pa smo jih nekoč po restavracijah kuhali v jušni zelenjavi, da je smrdelo povsod naokoli. V Ljubljani smo jih kuhali celo v hotelu Union in Turist, da o Figovcu in Šestici ne govorim. V slednji je bila prava uspešnica malo mešano – krožnik, na katerem so si vampi delili prostor z golažem. Po sicer cenjenih piranskih restavracijah pogrešam ponudbo te, lahko bi rekel danes že specialitete,« je ob kotličkih obujal kuharske spomine.

First they stink, then they go to everyone's delight
In Dragonja, they used to cook vamps in the Trieste way. Sometimes they were served even at weddings.
07 Nov 2019, 18:13 by Janez Male



For the tidiness of cooks, fireplaces, cleanliness and order in the kitchen, the team of Kažeta from Dragonja was the best rated.



On the way from one kettle to the next, visitors ate these sometimes much more common home-cooked dishes.



"Tripe in the Trieste way is a coastal dish, and at the end we are the only one with such a competition," says Mirjam Kastelic.



The structure of the vamps, their scent, color and of course the taste were evaluated by Branko Maksimovic, Igor Kramesteter and Mladen Orejas.



The best was cooked by a team of lovers of good food, company and joy Friends for ever from St. Petra. PHOTOS: Janez Muzic



Miran Velkavrh: "In Ljubljana, we even cooked them at the Union Hotel and Tourist, not to mention Figovac and Šestica."



They were a popular dish at work canteens, and so on. i. chauffeur's taverns, but today they are hard to order.


Some of the dishes that are adored by some, while others cuddle, are definitely beef vamps. They are prepared all over Slovenia, but the tripe in the Trieste way, as the Primorians call them, is their old dish. In fact, vampas are familiar with all European cuisines, especially the Spanish, French and Italian regions of the Mediterranean. Neighboring Italians even claim to be the world's biggest vamp lovers, since they are supposed to be prepared in a hundred ways and are considered part of their national cuisine. Particularly in Rome, they have always been great lovers of offal, which is called the quinto quarto or fifth quarter by the butchers as the more modest and also the poorer accessible meat.


They were a popular dish at work canteens, and so on. i. chauffeur's taverns, but today they are hard to order.

In eternal city, and wherever else, Saturday is the traditional day for vampas, called sabbatical trippa, when some indulge in breakfast. Of course, in addition to taste, tradition and perhaps even fashion, the fact that they are extremely cheap compared to other meat plays a significant role.
Gourmet specialty
Even in Istria and in the Primorska region in general, it has always been a highly regarded dish, but today it is popular with the older generation. It is known that our ancestors, when they went from village to town to work in larger cities, love to have a meal in a city outpost for a brunch. Later, after the war, they became a popular dish after the workers' and other canteens, and at all in t. i. chauffeur's inns, where they were offered virtually every day, much like goulash or other cheap snacks. But those times are past. They have been replaced by pizzas and they are also rarely cooked at home, since last but not least the raw in supermarkets is not always available.


The best was cooked by a team of lovers of good food, company and joy Friends for ever from St. Petra. PHOTOS: Janez Muzic

In addition, some are disturbed by the smell when preparing it, and god knows why young people, like any other offal, do not go too well. Perhaps that is why even though you won't find them on any of the finer restaurants, they are becoming a gourmet specialty. In recent years, we have even won some competitions in their preparation, or vampiades, in which more or less amateur chefs are measured in their preparation. In fact, we have no other way of cooking vamps than the Trieste family. Of course, these are minor modifications and to make it sound more homemade, some call it the Istrian tripe. Prepare them with roasted pancetta, onion, garlic, parsley and tomato sauce, and serve bread crumbs for thickening. Served with parmesan and bread, they are even better with polenta. And such Trips of Trieste were cooked last Saturday in October at the chestnut feast in Dragonja, which for the fourth year was enriched by the competition in their cooking.


The structure of the vamps, their scent, color and of course the taste were evaluated by Branko Maksimovic, Igor Kramesteter and Mladen Orejas.

“Our event is a village holiday, we started it seven years ago with chestnut. The event, of course, has the character of culinary socializing and friendship and was initially thematically colored with chestnut. This one fits nicely with the must these days. Every year, we add something new to our family, and four years ago, we added a cooking trip and a children's workshop where they make pumpkins, masks and other things for Halloween. Vamps are cooked all over Slovenia, but in a Trieste way they are a seafood dish, and in the end we are the only ones with such a competition, "says Mirjam Kastelič of Dragonja, president of Stena, an active development society there.
Caution when adding spices
Eight cooking teams came from Dragonja, the surrounding villages of Sv. Peter, Puce, Secovlje and even from the Poljanska Valley and Buj. After distributing three kilograms of boiled vamps to them, the special committee kept their eyes firmly on their toes. The contestants had to bring the rest of the ingredients themselves and arrange a tidy kitchen with their kettle above the hearth. It evaluated the firebox, the orderliness of the cooks, the space they clean behind, the cooking process and more. In the end, of course, it was the evaluation of the dishes, their structure, their smell, their color and their taste.


On the way from one kettle to the next, visitors ate these sometimes much more common home-cooked dishes.

“I have to admit that there is no stand out that some are extremely good and others are extremely bad. Some were over fat, others added too much tomato paste, some were crushed, but I liked that they didn't overdo spices. Most were too thick, too red or too pale, but for each team their vampas were certainly the best, and that's right. That's why they are all winners in a way, "said the chairman of the judging panel, Mladen Orejas, who is a chef at the Three Hunters Inn in Smarij. Beside him were a winemaker and a fruit grower from Dragonja, Igor Kramesteter and a retired journalist, now Piran 'professional' gourmet Branko Maksimovich.
Sometimes they were better
In ordering the kitchen and the teams won the team Kažeta from Dragonja, the second was the team Šavri from Puč and the third was the team Puč. The Friends for ever team from St. Petra in front of the team Shavri from Puch and the team Kumovi from Buj. They were certainly the most satisfied visitors to the event, who ate these sometimes much more common home-cooked meals while walking from one kettle to another.
4.You competed in a cooking trip.
The retired Piran chef, Miran Velkavrh, who cooked on the ships of General Navigation and the esteemed Piran restaurants, also came to try. “Precision in chopping onions, onion, garlic, bacon, and more, the order of raw material addition, and above all the precaution when adding spices, is important for preparing vamps. But sometimes the vamps themselves were different and tasted better than they are today. This was probably caused by a different breeding of cattle, their grazing, as well as the way they were cleaned and first cooked. Today you buy cooked and sliced or cooked ones, and we used to cook them in soup vegetables after restaurants, so it stinks everywhere. In Ljubljana, we even cooked them at the Union and Turist Hotel, not to mention Figovac and Šestica. In the latter, the real hit was a little mixed - a plate on which the vamps shared a space with a goulash. I miss the offer of this otherwise reputed Piran restaurant, I could say specialties today, ”he recalled the chef's memories at the kettle.
